title-group.article-title: Prediction of blast-induced vibration by adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system in Karoun 3 power plant and dam

abstract.p: In this research a study was conducted to predict the ground vibrations produced by blasting projects in the structures of Karoun 3 power plant and dam (Izeh town, Iran) using a conventional statistical approach and a relatively new soft computing method known as the adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system (ANFIS). For this aim a series of field measurements were planned and the required data were observed. A neuro-fuzzy model was constructed based on the data. In this model, the distance from the blasting site to the monitoring stations and the maximum charge weight per delay were selected as the input parameters of the constructed model, the output parameter being the peak particle velocity (PPV) as the vibration indicator. The results showed that the ANFIS model associated with the empirical model is a reliable and proper technique to predict the PPV caused from blasting.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Ground vibration is an undesirable by-product of blasting projects. As most mining and civil engineering constructions involve blasting, the vibration prediction and control are of great importance in such activities.

In the study area, there are some underground excavations which are being constructed and developed simultaneously using drilling and blasting techniques, and the produced vibrations from blasting can influence the stability and the newly constructed concrete and grouting in these structures. Thus, a vibration prediction study seemed to be critical in the area.

To evaluate the ground vibrations resulting from blasting activities, an index indicating the damage level of vibration is needed. Several indexes have been proposed by different authors and sources but the peak particle velocity (PPV) is the most reliable and suitable index as it has been used by many authors and researchers. For instance, PPV has been employed as a vibration index in Crandell’s Energy Ratio Concept (Crandell, 1949), Indian Standard Institute (1973), German DIN Standard 4150 (New, 1986), Indian CMRI standards (CMRI, 1993), Rockwell’s Energy Formula (Kahriman, 2002) and in the different empirical PPV predictor models such as Lundborg (1957), Duvall and Petkof (1959), Duvall and Fogelson (1962), Langefors and Kihlstrom (1963), Davies et al. (1964), Ambraseys and Hendron (1968), Holmberg and Persson (1979), Ghosh and Daemen (1983), Gupta et al. (1988), Roy (1993).

The nature and intensity of blast-induced ground vibrations and frequency are dependent upon many factors. These parameters are divided into two categories: controllable and uncontrollable parameters. Controllable parameters can be changed by the blaster in charge, while uncontrollable parameters are natural and cannot be controlled. For example, maximum charge per delay, total charge per round, distance from blast site, blast hole length, number of blast holes, total delay in millisecond, average specific charge, etc are controllable parameters, and rock conditions, topography, geology, rock properties, etc are uncontrolable parameters. It would be impractical to consider all these effective parameters in vibration analysis, and therefore only the most important ones are included in the model. Here, the input variables are the maximum charge per delay and distance from the blast site. The effect of other effective parameters are taken into account by some included constants and fitting parameters in the model.

In total there are two main approaches to predict the vibration: an empirical approach and a soft computing approach. In recent years, different researchers have employed empirical models to predict the PPV. A brief review of some of this work is given in Table 1. Table 1.

In this paper the empirical approach associated with a relatively new soft computing method known as the adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) were used to predict the PPV. In both models the maximum charge per delay and distance from blast site were taken into account as input parameters and the measured PPV as output parameter. Eventually, the results were compared and discussed.

sec.title: 2. Site description and data measurement
sec.p: The Karoun 3 project is located 28 km from Izeh town, Iran and is one of the greatest national projects being constructed. It consists of a complex of complicated excavations including a powerhouse complex, water shafts, tunnels, plunge pool, etc, which have close contact with each other. The project region has been located on sedimentary rocks. The bedrock is laid on limestone and marlstone rocks.

Because the excavations are too close to each other and are being simultaneously constructed using drilling and blasting techniques, the blasting projects should be performed based on vibration norms, thus the necessity of a vibration measuring and controlling program seemed to be critical, especially for the caverns of the power house and transformer, which have a large section area and sensitive stability. The perspective of Karoun 3 excavations are shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Perspective of Karoun 3 underground excavations.

To study the effects of blast vibrations in the excavations, data measurement operations were done with seismographs model UVS500 made by Nitro Nobel Company. The geophone can measure particles’ velocity in three main directions and resultant amplitude.

Installation coordinates of the geophone and blast center must be defined by mapping and surveying precisely in advance. Locations of 11 installed geophones in the Karoun 3 project are shown in Figure 2 with the numbers from 1 to 11. Figure 2.

sec.title: 3. Empirical approach
sec.p: Although there are different empirical PPV predictors suggested by different authors, the PPV predictor established by USBM (Duvall and Fogelson, 1962) is still the most widely used equation in the literature. The most reliable empirical equations are based upon scaled distance. The scaled distance is as a function of maximum charge per delay and distance from blast site. sec.title: 4.1. Concept and algorithm
sec.p: The adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system was developed by Jang (1993). It is a model that maps input characteristics to input membership functions and associated parameters, input membership function to rules, rules to a set of output characteristics, output characteristics to output membership functions and associated parameters, and the output membership function to a single-valued output or a decision associated with the output. The parameters associated with the membership functions change through the learning process until one of the stopping criteria is satisfied. The neuro-adaptive learning method works similarly to that of neural networks.

ANFIS is a soft computing technique which incorporates the concept of fuzzy logic into the neural networks, and has been widely used in many engineering applications (Akbulut et al., 2004; Gokceoglu et al., 2004; Porwal et al., 2004; Kisi, 2005; Singh et al., 2005b; Tutmez et al., 2006; Tutmez et al., 2007).

ANFIS can simulate and analyze the mapping relation between the input and output data through a hybrid learning to determine the optimal distribution of membership function. It is mainly based on the fuzzy “if–then” rules from the Takagi and Sugeno fuzzy model. It involves a premise part and a consequent part. The equivalent ANFIS architecture comprises five layers in this inference system and each layer involves several nodes, which are described by the node function (Iphar et al., 2008).

Here, square nodes, named adaptive nodes, are adopted to demonstrate that the parameter sets in these nodes are adjustable. Whereas circle nodes, named fixed nodes, are adopted to show that the parameter sets are fixed in the system.

The presented five-layer ANFIS with two fuzzy “if-then” rules, two inputs (x and y) and one output (f) in Figure 4, is described as follows (Jang, 1993; Jang et al., 1997):Layer 1:
every node in this layer is an adaptive node with a node output defined: (5)O1,i=μAi(x) fori=1,…,m or (6)O1,i=μBi(y) fori=1,…,m
Where x (or y) is the input to the node i, Ai (Bi) is the ith fuzzy set associated with the membership function of this node, and m is the number of fuzzy sets for each input parameter. In other words, μAi is the membership grade of a fuzzy set A.

The nodes in this layer are square nodes, with parameters representing the shape and the center of each fuzzy set (antecedent parameters). The output of this layer is the value of membership functions evaluated for a set of input variables.Layer 2:
every node in this layer is a fixed node, marked by a circle node, labeled ∏, which multiplies the incoming signals and outputs the product. (7)O2,i=wi=μAi(x).μBi(y) i=1,2
The output signal wi denotes the firing strength of a rule. The number of nodes of this layer equals the number of fuzzy if-then rules in the fuzzy inference system.Layer 3:
every node i in this layer is a fixed node, marked by a circle node, labeled N. The ith node calculates the ratio of the ith rule’s firing strength to the sum of all rules’ firing strengths: (8)O3,i=w¯i=wiw1+w2 i=1,2
For convenience, outputs of this layer are called normalized firing strengths. The nodes in this layer are circle nodes and thus do not have any unknown parameters.Layer 4:
every node in this layer is an adjustable node, marked by a square node, with the node function as: (9)O4,i=w¯ifi=w¯i (pix+qiy+ri ) Where wi is the output of Layer 3 and {pi, qi, ri} is the parameter set of this node. Parameters in this layer are referred to as consequent parameters.Layer 5:
The single node in this layer is a fixed node labeled Σ that computes the overall output as the summation of all incoming signals by: (10)O5,i=∑w¯ifi=∑iwifi∑iwi
Explicitly, this layer sums the node’s output in the previous layer to be the output of the whole network.

The parameters associated with the membership functions change through the learning process. The computation of these parameters (or their adjustment) is facilitated by a gradient vector. This gradient vector provides a measure of how well the fuzzy inference system is modeling the input/output data for a given set of parameters. When the gradient vector is obtained, any of several optimization routines can be applied in order to adjust the parameters to reduce some error measure. This error measure is defined by the sum of the squared difference between actual and desired outputs (SSE). ANFIS uses either back propagation or a combination of least squares estimation and back-propagation (the hybrid learning procedure) for membership function parameter estimation.

There are two passes in the hybrid learning procedure for ANFIS. In the forward pass of the hybrid-learning algorithm, functional signals go forward till layer 4 and the consequent parameters are identified by the least-squares estimate. In the backward pass, the error rates propagate backward and the premise parameters are updated by the gradient descent. When the values of the premise parameters are fixed, the overall output can be expressed as a linear combination of the consequent parameters (Iphar et al., 2008): (11)f=w1w1+w2f1+w2w1+w2f2=w¯1 (p1x+q1y+r1 )+w¯2 (p2x+q2y+r2 ) which is linear in consequent parameters (p1, q1, r1, p2, q2, r2).

sec.title: 4.2. Data Analysis by ANFIS
sec.p: The measured data set including 29 samples was subdivided into two groups: 23 samples (80%) were used for training and six remained samples were employed for checking in order to prevent from over-fitting. To analyze the data using the ANFIS approach, a MALAB (2006) program was used.

A Sugeno fuzzy model was employed. To select the membership functions and their characteristics, there has been no general rule until now because it depends on different factors. Different membership functions were tried and the result was that Gaussian membership function had comparatively reliable results and also Gaussian membership functions are more common in fuzzy systems literature, as they provide both simplicity and flexibility (Tutmez et al., 2007). Therefore, Gaussian membership function was used for the input variables as: (12)f(x;σ,c)=e- (x-c )22σ2 Where x is the input variable, σ and c are the adjustable parameters of this membership function (premise parameters). The input variables – i.e. distance from blast site, D, and maximum charge per delay, W- have been divided into three groups and a membership function is assigned for each group as: Low, Medium and High values (Figures 4 and 5). A linear membership function with three consequent parameters was considered for the output (PPV). There are nine rules in the used ANFIS architecture (Figure 6). Since each membership function has two adjustable parameters (σ and c), there are 3 × 2 × 2 adjustable parameters (premise parameters) for the membership functions of inputs. In Layer 3, the number of consequent parameters was 27 (3 × 9), as there are nine linear membership functions of the output parameter (because one output membership function is assigned for each rule) and three consequent parameters (pi, q i, ri) of a linear membership function. The hybrid optimization method was employed in order to estimate the parameters of membership functions. After 904 epochs the error of training process did not change and remained 0.06114 (Figure 7). Figure 7.

sec.title: 5. Results and discussion
sec.p: As mentioned above, in this study the peak particle velocity produced from the blasting projects in the study area was predicted using two alternatives: empirical and ANFIS.

The results of the methods used showed that there is a very high correlation between the PPV predicted by ANFIS and the observed PPV (Figure 8) and also there is a suitable correlation between the PPV predicted by the empirical equation (equation (4)) and the observed PPV (Figure 9). Figure 8.
Predicted peak particle velocity (PPV) by adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system approach versus the observed PPV.
Figure 9.
Predicted peak particle velocity (PPV) by empirical approach versus the observed PPV.

To illustrate and compare the error of estimation for each data sample using each technique, the results were compared (Figure 10). It is not unexpected that ANFIS has a better answer than the empirical formula because it has 39 fitting parameters (12 premise parameters plus 27 three consequent parameters) whereas the empirical equation has only two (K1 and K2 in equation (4)). Figure 10.
Comparison between predicted peak particle velocity (PPV) by adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system and empirical with observed PPV.

In fact, both of the techniques have applicability in practice, depending on the situation. When the need is to predict the PPV with high accuracy and certainty, the ANFIS approach would be the proper alternative, and in a situation in which a graph or a reliable formula are needed to predict the maximum charge pre delay for a given distance from the blast site the empirical formula could be an easy-to-access and use solution in the field investigations. For this reason by using equation (4) and the US Bureau of Mines Standards for blast vibrations based on PPV, a standard graph was achieved for the study area (Figure 11). Figure 11.
Prediction of maximum charge per delay for a given distance from blast site.
Using Figure 11 the maximum charge per delay, W, can be estimated for a given distance from blast site and an allowable PPV value.

sec.title: 6. Conclusion
sec.p:
The most important concern of the blasting projects in the Karoun 3 project area is the blast-induced ground vibrations, because its underground excavations are too close to each other. Thus, the necessity of a scientific analysis of the vibration was found to be essential in order to predict and control the vibrations. The peak particle velocity (PPV) was considered as a vibration index. To predict the PPV, two methods were employed–empirical and adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system. The following results were concluded:
Although the correlation of the ANFIS results is much more than empirical approach, each alternative has its usage. The ANFIS method is used when a highly accurate and reliable PPV prediction is needed and the empirical approach can be used as an easy-to- access and use alternative.
By using the obtained empirical equation and the US Bureau of Mines Standards for blast vibrations based on PPV, a standard graph was achieved for study area. Using such a graph, the maximum charge per delay, W, can be estimated for a given distance from blast site and an allowable PPV value.
As the distance from the blast site decreases, the PPV value would be sensitive to the amount of maximum charge per delay based on the obtained graph. Therefore in close distances this important point should be taken into consideration.
To establish an ANFIS model, there is no general rule to select the model’s characteristics such as type of membership functions, number of membership function, parameters of membership functions, etc. In this study different characteristics were tried and the correct one was selected based on rule of thumb.
Eventually, the results indicated that two used models complete each other. The ANFIS method is a very accurate approach and the empirical technique has a mathematical equation and is easy-to-use and access. Therefore they complete each other and the ANFIS method associated with the empirical approach can satisfy all necessary requirements to predict and control vibrations.
